Solve the differential equation found in part (a).

To solve the differential equation, separate the variables.

hints_raw:
Solve the differential equation found in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2011/Question_05_(a)|part (a)]].
To solve the differential equation, separate the variables.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
Recall that the differential equation is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dS}{dt} = 1.9 - \frac1{20}S\end{aligned}\]

We use separation of variables and bring all terms with S to the left hand side, and all terms involving t to the right hand side. So we multiply both sides with \(\displaystyle dt\) and divide by \(\displaystyle 1.9 - \frac1{20}S\):

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = dt\end{aligned}\]

Let’s now integrate both sides:

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = \int dt\end{aligned}\]

The integral on the right hand side is simply \(\displaystyle t+C_1.\) To solve the left hand side, use the substitution \(u = 1.9 - \frac{1}{20}S,\ dS=-20\,du\) and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = \int \frac{-20\,du}{u} = -20 \ln|u| = -20 \ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| = t+C_1.\end{aligned}\]

Solving the above for S yields

\[\begin{aligned} -20 \ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= t+C_1 \\ \ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= -\frac{t}{20}-\frac{C_1}{20} \\ \left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= e^{-\frac{t}{20}-\frac{C_1}{20}} \\ 1.9-\frac{S}{20} &= \pm e^{-\frac{C_1}{20}} e^{-\frac{t}{20}}\\ S &= 20\left(1.9-C_2 e^{-t/20}\right), \end{aligned}\]

with a different constant \(C_2 = \pm e^{-C_1/20}\). Now we use the initial condition S(0) = 0 to solve for C2:

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = 20\left(1.9-C_2 e^{0}\right) = 20(1.9-C_2),\end{aligned}\]

hence C2 = 1.9 and therefore the final answer is

\[\begin{aligned} S(t) = 20\left(1.9-1.9e^{-t/20}\right).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Recall that the differential equation is given by

:<math> \frac{dS}{dt} = 1.9 - \frac1{20}S </math>

We use separation of variables and bring all terms with ''S'' to the left hand side, and all terms involving ''t'' to the right hand side. So we multiply both sides with <math>\displaystyle dt</math> and divide by <math>\displaystyle  1.9 - \frac1{20}S</math>:


:<math> \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = dt </math>


Let's now integrate both sides:


:<math> \int \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = \int dt </math>


The integral on the right hand side is simply <math>\displaystyle t+C_1. </math> To solve the left hand side, use the substitution <math> u = 1.9 - \frac{1}{20}S,\ dS=-20\,du</math> and obtain

:<math> \int \frac{dS}{1.9 - \frac1{20}S} = \int \frac{-20\,du}{u} = -20 \ln|u| = -20 \ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| = t+C_1. </math>

Solving the above for ''S'' yields

:<math> \begin{align}
-20 \ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= t+C_1 \\
\ln\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= -\frac{t}{20}-\frac{C_1}{20} \\
\left|1.9-\frac{S}{20}\right| &= e^{-\frac{t}{20}-\frac{C_1}{20}} \\
1.9-\frac{S}{20} &= \pm e^{-\frac{C_1}{20}} e^{-\frac{t}{20}}\\
S &= 20\left(1.9-C_2 e^{-t/20}\right), 
\end{align}</math>

with a different constant <math>C_2 = \pm e^{-C_1/20}</math>. Now we use the initial condition ''S(0) = 0'' to solve for ''C<sub>2</sub>'':

:<math> 0 = 20\left(1.9-C_2 e^{0}\right) = 20(1.9-C_2), </math>

hence ''C<sub>2</sub> = 1.9'' and therefore the final answer is

:<math> S(t) = 20\left(1.9-1.9e^{-t/20}\right). </math>
statement_html:
Bird-Bath and Beyond Incorporated is famous for its Quetzal attracting bird-feeder solution made from water, honey and cane-sugar.

To make their solution, both honey and a cane-sugar solution are poured into a 200 L mixing tank. The honey is poured in at a rate of 1 L per minute while the sugar solution is poured in at 9 L per minute. Note that 1 L of honey contains 1 kg of sugar, while the cane-sugar solution contains 100g of sugar per L.

Unfortunately today there is a problem with the mixing tank. It was thoroughly cleaned and is initially filled with pure water, but main valve was broken and the water cannot be drained. When the mixing process is started, the honey and sugar-solutions are poured into the tank, and the excess fluid flows out of an emergency valve at 10 L per minute and onto the floor. You should assume that the solutions mix immediately and thoroughly in the tank.

(b) How much sugar is in the tank after time t?
statement_latex:
Bird-Bath and Beyond Incorporated is famous for its Quetzal attracting
bird-feeder solution made from water, honey and cane-sugar.

To make their solution, both honey and a cane-sugar solution are poured
into a 200 L mixing tank. The honey is poured in at a rate of 1 L per
minute while the sugar solution is poured in at 9 L per minute. Note
that 1 L of honey contains 1 kg of sugar, while the cane-sugar solution
contains 100g of sugar per L.

Unfortunately today there is a problem with the mixing tank. It was
thoroughly cleaned and is initially filled with pure water, but main
valve was broken and the water cannot be drained. When the mixing
process is started, the honey and sugar-solutions are poured into the
tank, and the excess fluid flows out of an emergency valve at 10 L per
minute and onto the floor. You should assume that the solutions mix
immediately and thoroughly in the tank.

(b) How much sugar is in the tank after time \emph{t}?
statement_raw:
Bird-Bath and Beyond Incorporated is famous for its Quetzal attracting bird-feeder solution made from water, honey and cane-sugar.

To make their solution, both honey and a cane-sugar solution are poured into a 200 L mixing tank. The honey is poured in at a rate of 1 L per minute while the sugar solution is poured in at 9 L per minute. Note that 1 L of honey contains 1 kg of sugar, while the cane-sugar solution contains 100g of sugar per L.

Unfortunately today there is a problem with the mixing tank. It was thoroughly cleaned and is initially filled with pure water, but main valve was broken and the water cannot be drained. When the mixing process is started, the honey and sugar-solutions are poured into the tank, and the excess fluid flows out of an emergency valve at 10 L per minute and onto the floor.
You should assume that the solutions mix immediately and thoroughly in the tank.

(b) How much sugar is in the tank after time ''t''?
